comments.commentBody: Prof. Krugman has been a very vocal and persistent advocate of stimulus spending to increase demand.  You are absolutely wrong to claim otherwise.
You obviously haven't been reading Dr. Krugman very long.  He's been arguing for a stimulus spending since the crisis hit.
Maybe you have missed the thrust of Krugman's many editorials. He has advocated stimulus tirelessly.

Paul Krugman writes we must stem our losses from Republican's economically destructive obsession with cutting safety nets and redistributing taxpayer dollars upward. Not a word on investing in our economy to create jobs, by using fiscal policy as even Republican Ben Bernanke has been saying for years.

I read op-editorialist Scott J. Brown yesterday, arguing in Room for Debate that defense spending cuts have a high multiple, meaning that every dollar cut from defense spending may subtract $2 from the overall economy! The fact that weaponized Keynsianism hides itself behind made-up words like multiple, instead of multiplier, with unsupported scary 2-for-1 loss predictions, was disconcerting.

This kind of weaponized Keynsianism, that dares not speak it's name, displaces the more proven multiplier effects of stimulation directly at aimed at increasing demand. It gives cover to politicians who want to ignore multipliers proven by history and acknowleged by the IMF. It's like Republican ranting that that public spending always displaces private spending (jobs), even when the FED cannot lower interest rates. And obscures that stimulating economic growth and job creation is far less important to deficit hawksters, than upward redistribution of tax dollars.

But for Dr. Krugman to be telling us our best action is not to demand revenue and stimulus, but to just try to keep the deficit hawksters at bay, that's what's really scary. Thanks Citizen United's right wing propaganda.

Thank you Dr. Walaszek for some common sense. This article and many of the comments are over focused on the possibility that a practitioner might label a person as ill, as if that was a matter of opinion. The plain truth is that sufferers come to us. Thhey know they're ill. They know they don't want to suffer further. Whereas, it can be palliative to a degree, to normalize their pain (ie; explaining the average course of grief), often that's not enough. Many of these comments seem to assert that the lion share of pain is coming from a belief on the part of the sufferer that they ought not be in pain. Hence they are abnormal. This is ridiculous. The pain of depression is as real as the pain of a toothache. Its not anyone's (psychiatrist, philosopher, etc...) job to judge the validity of that pain based on prevalence, causation, social values, etc... The job's to fix it. Period.

rm -- We now have ten carriers, since Enterprise retired (already torn apart) and its replacement is some years away. We have two rotating through shipyard availability almost all the time. Right now we have a new one doing prolonged workups. Half of the rest are at home doing necessary training and workups. So our entire deployable force at any one time is three or four. One of those is home ported permanently in Japan. So apart from the Japan carrier, three is the whole Navy available at most times. We can "surge" by delaying repair and shortening training, but that is temporary. We recently did do a surge off Iran, and now are paying for that.

We now have one in the Persian Gulf. We cancelled the second one that was to go, and the crews are now formally notified they will remain at home to save money. If it does not go, it is hard to see where a second could come from, much less a third. The current locations are public: http://www.gonavy.jp/CVLocation.html

We had 15 for many years, with two permanently in the Med and one in Japan. That time is gone. Popular understanding hasn't caught up.

Also, our carriers can handle about twice the aircraft they now carry. They don't because the US does not have the aircraft. Even now some F-18s are turned over from a returning carrier to a departing carrier.

Mind you, we pay more for this smaller Navy. Some of that is inevitable. Some of that is the Military Industrial Complex is winning its real priorities.

We all are going to die, and we all know it, except for small children, but we aren't all depressed about it, and few of us require antidepressants to live with the knowledge without a sense of meaninglessness.  When I see my grandson smile, or read about a good Samaritan who rushes into a burning building to save a stranger, I feel a sense of meaning.

IowaJack: What exactly would you like from psychiatry given your aversion to death? That you aren't happy with the prospect of non-existence is not a fault of psychiatry or anyone else.

At the same type one can share your beliefs about death and not be depressed.

You are describing "melancholia", "spleen" "la noia" whatever. Different words to describe the distress that a lot of people who are insightful, sensitive, articulate, and not dumbed by religion (I include the religion of rationality and science) experience. You are right: what are we here for? nobody knows. That is hard, particularly is one accepts the fact that there is no answer, and the fear and anxiety that follows. Sartre, Camus, Moravia, Shakespeare and the earlier ones (greeks, latins, I don't know much about oriental cultures) have said it all. It is what it is.

So it is claimed that bereavement results from the loss of another? And that the symptoms of bereavement are equal to depression, yet of shorter duration.

My bereavement and its depression symptoms grew from my realization that I will die.

I don't understand how anyone can enjoy this life knowing that it ends, and without any meaning. Even those who are helped by one's life will, themselves, die and lose the effects of any contributions.

Of course I don't accept the claims of religions that want my allegiance and donations. History is rife with disparate groups 'inventing' their gods as a path to avoid physical death, the endlessness of nothing.

What is one to do after acknowledging the truths of life and death? Psychiatrists today interview a little and select a concoction from a shelf, as do Chinese pharmacists. What can this do for me? Forget my death? Numb me so it matters not?

Cymbalta and Abilify may enable one to shake hands and pat backs like a Carnegie sales training grad. But the sadness and emptiness of internal self-bereavement continues without abatement.

Linda in St. Croix Falls - "It's a great life if you don't weaken" was my mother's answer each time life threw us a curve ball. She died two years ago aged 89 and it was one of the last things she said to me.

The day I lost my brother, my cousin simply said, "I am your brother now." And he was, for twenty four more years until AIDS took him. I was the last one he saw the night he died. I am wearing his gold signet ring as I write. I always wear it when I'm in a difficult situation. It reminds me he is with me.

I have not crossed over to that place where one is more grateful for what they had than for the loss. I'm in awe of those who can do this.

You were both very blessed.

I too, at least on paper, am supposed to be represented by Boehner. Boehner enjoys such popularity in his district that he is usually re-elected by margins of about 70%, I can only remember one election about two years ago that there was even a serious Democrat running against him. There are no Democrats holding office in Butler County and there is no liklihood that there will be one in the forseeable future. The Democratic party is almost non-existant. There are two former Republican officeholders now in federal prison for hanky-panky with money but what the hey, they may be crooks but they are our crooks.

Boehner is so beholden to K Street that he rakes in millions of dollars in campaign contributions. He does not need the money so he gives it to other Republicans. They have rewarded him with the Speakership. I say that in all his years in Washington he has never been responsible for any important piece of legislation. I have the great misfortune to be represented by John Boehner. I am also losing my job due to the sequester. Even worse, the Dayton area, which is heavily dependent on Wright Patterson and military spending, is about to get smacked down by the sequester. News in the paper today is that federal employees will be fuloughed one day a week, resulting in what amounts to a 20% pay cut.

I am a dedicated Obama supporter, think the defense department could be cut, but this is no way to do it. Southwestern Ohio is barely recovering from the loss of thousands of manufacturing jobs - we don't need this too. Certainly we could manage trimming spending in a more responsible way than the way it will happen under the sequester.

Has John Boehner done one thing, just one, to help his constituents weather this mess? I am here to tell you that he has not. He is absolutely useless as an advocate for us.

Just one more reason to never, ever, ever vote Republican again.

Revwayne, I like your neat statement about Republicans wanting to give zygotes full human rights, except for the second half about them wanting to treat any humans out of the womb with "irreverence".  Sorry for nitpicking, but "irreverence" sugarcoats the disdain that Republicans have for the American poor, elderly and disabled.  Someone else said it neatly as well when he said that Republicans were pro-life until you're born, and then they believe in every man for himself.

revwayne, small correction here: If Medicaid for seniors in nursing homes is cut, the difference will be made up by raising rates for the private pay patients. They will then deplete their assets even more rapidly after entering a nursing home and are more likely to die destitute. Their families who might have had a small inheritance to build their own retirement nest egg will have nothing.

This is a missing "domino" in your thinking and the most significant one.

I have not heard many specific budget reduction proposals from Mr. Boehner. Entitlement programs are often suggested. So, let's act on Mr. Ryan's (v-p candidate & apparent financial whiz) proposal to cut Medicaid. Seniors in nursing homes will receive less. The next domino to be affected, of course, is the nursing home will receive less funds. To cope with the decrease in receipts homes will need to reduce their costs. How? Fewer employees or benefits or wage reduction or ... will be necessary. Are most nursing home staff overpaid, provided costly pension and health care benefits? Doubtful. Some employees will be added to the unemployment rolls, others will have less purchasing power, and less income means less taxes paid. And, there will be nursing home facilities which close. What becomes of the senior citizens where the staff is cut or the home declares bankruptcy?

I find the Republican approach to budget reduction - the little that has been suggested - very disturbing. Immoral. A party that wants to give a zygote full human rights, but would treat any human out of the womb (mothers, children, laborers, senior citizens....) with such irreverence is disheartening.

Do you work in a big company? Inefficiencies in governement and not in big companies? That is a myth. Actually a joke. Profit is less of a motive to be efficient today. You can always lay off a few workers to get profit. And what does a CEO care if the company goes bust they can always find another job if need be which of course there won't be a need because of the golden parachute in  their contract. They get the bucks even if the company fails or they fail. Don't you get that? When businesses were owned by the guy at the top all that profit incentive may have been true but today no one really cares about the company. You are living in the past.

And I suppose the financial sector's party they threw with our home equity, 401K's, government pension funds and bank deposits was the model of efficient, productive management in the face of profit and loss incentives?

Give us a break with the holier-than-thou stuff. What you mean is, it's OK to be a drunk if you consume $300-a-bottle wine, but anyone who'd let a Budweiser pass his lips is disposable.

Let's look at the profit incentives that you touted as causing "private providers" to improve the quality of their service, with regard to our private health insurance industry.  The quality of service to whom?  Whom do they serve?  The record shows that they serve the shareholders, less so their patients.  Medicare has  a fraction of the "administrative" costs of the private insurers.  The shareholders are parasitic towards delivery of healthcare.

The question of whether or not government spending is always going to be less productive than private spending is ultimately an empirical one. We can say that in principle, we would expect this to be the case. If you are spending your own money on yourself, you are going to do it very carefully. If you are spending somebody else's money on yourself, you are also going to be reasonably careful about it. However if you are spending somebody else's money on somebody else (which is what is the case with government), then you have no real incentive to use that money effectively or efficiently and there are many examples from history that bear this out. There is a case for saying that there are certain kinds of spending which are more efficient when carried out by government because of the economies of scale that government possesses. However this is almost always outweighed (I would argue, in fact, always outweighed) by the huge inefficiency costs that come with the less productive public management and the fact that public provision does not face the profit and loss incentives which lead private providers to constantly look to improve the quality of their service and cut out waste and unnecessary costs.

Individuals should have the freedom to use whatever the fancy for money. Pursuing this course of action may be a little painful in the short-run but what hangover is not painful. It’s better to slowly reset our monetary system than try to drink (QE3) ourselves into sobriety!
